awd_abstract_narration:
An exciting aspect of any scientific research, in particular in mathematics, is the opportunity to merge a priori disparate phenomena into a unified theory. Such unification makes research more efficient overall, reduces duplication, and fosters creativity. The transposition of technical methods from one field to another, in potentially unexpected ways, not only strengthens research but often inspires new ideas that lead to breakthroughs. This project is concerned with such a unification, known as "Tensor-Triangular Geometry," that merges aspects of topology, algebraic geometry, representation theory and of other areas of mathematics under a single umbrella. In this project, Tensor-Triangular Geometry will be deployed at the interface of modular representation theory of finite groups and the theory of motives in number theory. The explicit nature of the former enhances our understanding of the latter, providing classification results among other applications. Graduate students will be trained through the research.
 
The specific objectives of this project are the classifications of objects that appear in two categories in two distinct areas. On one hand, one can consider Artin-Tate motives over various ground fields in Voevodsky's derived category of motives, and on the other one can consider complexes of filtered representations over pro-finite groups, typically the absolute Galois groups of the above fields. Thanks to tensor-triangular geometry, such classifications are equivalent to the computation of a space (the spectrum) associated to the categories in question. The proposed methods involve etale extensions in tensor-triangular geometry. These extensions are a new development that have incarnations in both settings, as finite extensions of the ground field in the motivic case and as the corresponding restriction to finite-index subgroups in the equivariant case. Understanding Artin-Tate motives via filtered representations in turn sheds new light on the classification of objects in the larger and more mysterious category of motives, which is a long-term goal of researchers in the field.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The major research outcomes include:

  1. Finite Permutation Resolutions over Finite Groups: The objective is to comprehend situations in which a finitely generated RG-module M has a finite resolution involving permutation RG-modules. It was developed in collaboration with Martin Gallauer. This exploration is essential due to the contrast between the simplicity of permutation modules and the complexity of general representation theory with coefficients in a ring R. The research is divided into regular and singular cases. In the regular case, a permutation resolution is always attainable. In the singular case, a novel invariant named "cohomological singularity" is developed to quantify obstructions to such resolutions. This invariant combines group cohomology and a singular functor.

  2. Cohomological Mackey 2-Functors: The endeavor focuses on extending the concept of cohomological Mackey functors into the realm of Mackey 2-functors. In collaboration with Ivo Dell'Ambrogio, the PI defines "cohomological Mackey two-functors" and explores their properties. These abstractions provide insights into both ordinary and motivic Mackey functors. The research also culminates in a theorem that relates cohomological Mackey 2-motives to permutation bimodules and equivariant maps.

Intellectual Merit: This project centers on deepening the understanding of tensor-triangulated categories, a unifying concept across mathematics like algebraic geometry, stable homotopy theory, modular representation theory, and motivic theory. It introduces an abstract support theory for significant objects within these categories, addressing gaps in various fields, especially motivic contexts. This novel tool enhances researchers' capacity to analyze complex structures and relationships.

Broader Impact: Advancements in this project resonate beyond tensor-triangular geometry, influencing fields like stable homotopy theory, algebraic geometry, and more. The collaboration with Martin Gallauer illuminates connections in modular representation theory, algebraic geometry, and equivariant homotopy theory. The interdisciplinary approach encourages cross-field insights, fostering collaboration, inspiring new questions, and promoting innovative methodologies. It underscores the value of interdisciplinary research, potentially leading to transformative breakthroughs while enriching diverse mathematical domains.
